awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Digital platform to manage the care of the elderly by utilizing long-term services and support resources
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a digital tool that connects the elderly and their family caregivers to resources, education, and services in the eldercare assistance industry. The proposed technology is designed for family caregivers to access the device through a smartphone application where they may connect with service providers for assistance with various aspects of eldercare, including home-aids, medical providers, elder law resources, and many other commonly sought services. The technology may improve caregivers’ experiences by providing tailored information that helps connect them with the community of support services appropriate for them. The aim of this technology is to increase caregiver confidence and utilization of community and remote resources available to them. Numerous resources for family caregivers have been developed previously. However, the adoption rate of these resources remains low due to lack of easy access, non-personalized information, information complexity, and a poor user experience.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a novel Care Personalization Algorithm (CPA) that creates a user-specific intervention best suited for each caregiver. The demands of caregiving change over time and each caregiver's financial, legal, geographic, and familial situation is unique. This requires that digital services to assist caregivers be highly personalized. The proposed technology addresses this issue by developing a digital platform based on logic decision trees (based on key caregiver characteristics input by the user) and geolocation (automatically obtained from the mobile phone).  The technology will generate personalized information, recommendations, and interactive checklists for each caregiver to assist with the legal, financial, health, social assistance and other challenges of caregiving. The proposed design may provide caregivers with a customized caregiver plan that may narrow the information they seek and provide a listing of resources and service-providers directed to their needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Olera team completed 100 interviews with family caregivers of those with dementia and service providers that care for people living with dementia in order to inform the development a novel Care Personalization Algorithm (CPA) that creates a user-specific intervention best suited for each caregiver. Specifically, we learned that the algorithm will be using logic decision trees (based on key caregiver characteristics input by the user) and geolocation (automatically obtained from the mobile phone) to generate personalized information, recommendations, and interactive checklists for each caregiver to assist with the legal, financial, health, social assistance and other challenges of caregiving. 

Details on our findings are below:

1)What information brings caregivers the most value? We found that caregivers are most interested in discovering what questions they should be asking. For example, caregivers were unaware of the many services that exist to assist them in their community including caregivers support groups, churches, and volunteer respite services. Caregivers also appreciated the information about when to transition to certain levels of professional care. It was noted that education on the transition from in-home care to professional, facility-based care would be of value to caregivers. Additionally, caregivers were excited about the information that would allow them to “age-in-place” or maintain quality of life in the home as long as possible.

 2)How do needs differ among caregiver subgroups? We discovered that caregivers can be segmented into the following sub-groups: spouse caregivers, adult child caregivers, and distance caregivers. Spouse caregivers were typically older and are not as interested in new, innovative ways of disseminating information on caregiving. The adult child caregivers and distance caregivers were typically more open to digital technology as a medium of delivery of caregiving education and recommendations. These subgroups were roughly between the ages of 35-55 years old.

 3)How is caregiver information best presented to users through the Olera Platform? Caregivers reported that information could be best presented through a mobile phone application or website; however, information complexity and overload are a large risk for the adoptability and usefulness of the information. Multiple caregivers interviewed quoted that many websites exist to help caregivers educate themselves on important caregiving topics; however, these websites have limited helpfulness due to a non-personalized nature, long text-based delivery methods (articles/informational pieces), and overwhelming volume leading to choose paralysis.

The team has used the information learned from the ICorps Teams experience to inform their Phase I and II SBIR awarded in September 2021. The team is developing the Care Personalization algorithm to help connect caregivers to the education and services providers in their local area with hopes to improve the self-efficacy of caregivers with arranging and managing the care of someone with dementia.

Key outcomes or Other achievements:

The work on this project led to a NIH National Institute on Aging Small Business Innovation Research grant (RFA-AG-21-025; Award Number: 1R44AG074116-01 Fast-Track, total $2.3 million). The results served as preliminary work to build off of in Phase I and Phase II SBIR studies.
